title: 113_hr2230
content: The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes sections on improved climate assessments, service-wide 360 assessments, health welfare inspections, and reviews of security and diversity management in the military. It also authorizes appropriations. Congress found an increase in reported sexual assault cases in the Armed Forces in fiscal year 2012, with 26,000 anonymous reports. Female members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77% also facing sexual harassment, while male members experienced similar issues. In fiscal year 2012, 77% of female Armed Forces members experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 62% facing some form of retaliation. Commanders must conduct climate assessments to create a safe environment and identify harmful behaviors like sexual harassment and assault early on. Commanders at all levels must ensure a safe environment by identifying trends in bad behavior like sexual harassment and assault. Improved performance assessments and better reporting are needed to address these issues. Members often do not report incidents due to fear of repercussions on their military career. Ignoring sexual misconduct by commanders perpetuates this behavior. Members often do not report incidents of sexual misconduct in the military due to fear of repercussions on their career. Commanders condoning or ignoring such behavior perpetuates a culture that obstructs change. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "sexual harassment" is defined in Department of Defense Directive 1350.2, and "sexual assault" refers to offenses described in section 920 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 4. IMPROVED CLIMATE ASSESSMENTS AND DISSEMINATION AND TRACKING OF RESULTS. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Each military department must include a designated form in performance evaluations for senior commanders to indicate if required climate assessments were conducted. Failure to conduct assessments will be noted in evaluations and impact consideration for promotion. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor commanders' compliance with conducting command climate assessments. Unit commanders, in collaboration with the Inspector General, will compile climate assessments to create compliance reports detailing member concerns and perceptions of leadership within the unit. Unit commanders in the Department of Defense must gather climate assessments from their units to create compliance reports. These reports should include member concerns, perceptions of leadership, and a strategic plan to address the expressed issues. The Secretary of Defense mandates the inclusion of reprimands, counseling statements, and actions related to sexual harassment or assault in performance evaluations of Armed Forces members. This is to increase visibility, identify trends of misconduct early, discipline repeat offenders, and prevent the transfer of sexual offenders. Additionally, there is a provision for service-wide 360 assessments. SEC. 6 mandates the adoption of a 360-degree assessment program by military departments and includes individual counseling in performance evaluations. A report on the feasibility of including the 360-degree approach in performance evaluation reports is also required. SEC. 7 mandates monthly health welfare inspections by military department Secretaries to ensure security, readiness, and discipline in Armed Forces units. Results are reported to commanders. SEC. 8 requires a review of security in military installations, including barracks and residences. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and residences to ensure safety. This includes identifying security gaps and evaluating the use of electronic monitoring or security personnel at entry points. Results must be submitted within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense will assess security measures at military installations, specifically focusing on barracks and residences to address security gaps. A report with cost estimates to eliminate identified gaps and implement 24-hour security monitoring must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 9. The Secretary of Defense will review the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity to identify resource gaps, assess its role in sexual harassment cases, and evaluate its collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. SEC. 10. Appropriations are authorized for the Secretary of Defense to implement the Act in fiscal year 2014.
